page.title: 03Adisham Farming, types
page.content: The farming pattern at Adisham has scarcely changed since the monks of Christ Church Canterbury grew corn and ran sheep over the Downs. There are now four farms in the area, two corn growing of six to seven hundred acres and two dairy farms, one of l30 acres with 100 cows and the other 240 acres with 80 milking cows, 65 followers and 40 sheep. Both of these use mechanical milking and the milk is collected by the Milk Marketing Board for distribution. The chief land-owners are the Church Commissioners and a Lord resident in an adjacent village, who has increased his estate by absorbing smaller farms. The corn lands were formerly fenced but now remain open fields of 50 to 100 acres for easy working by tractor and combine harvester. Some other mixed farms penetrate the perimeter.
